stem: A 34-week pregnant client with preeclampsia is being evaluated for worsening malaise. Based on the documentation, which finding is the MOST definitive indicator of hemolysis?

options.text: Presence of schistocytes on the peripheral blood smear
Report of right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain

rationale.correct: The presence of schistocytes on the peripheral blood smear (a1) is the most definitive indicator of hemolysis in HELLP syndrome. Schistocytes are fragmented red blood cells that are 'shredded' as they pass through small, fibrin-clotted vessels. This microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is a hallmark of HELLP syndrome. While elevated LDH and bilirubin suggest cell breakdown, they are not as specific as the presence of schistocytes.
clinicalPearls: HELLP syndrome is characterized by Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelets.
Schistocytes, also known as 'helmet cells,' are broken red blood cells.
Low haptoglobin levels indicate increased hemolysis, as haptoglobin binds to free hemoglobin.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting RUQ pain (a3) because it is a common symptom of HELLP syndrome.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: RUQ pain indicates elevated liver enzymes or liver swelling, but it is not specific to hemolysis. Focus on the lab findings that directly indicate red blood cell destruction.

mnemonic.title: HELLP Smear
mnemonic.expansion: HE-Hemolysis. EL-Elevated Liver enzymes. LP-Low Platelets. Smear-Schistocytes (Broken Cells).

exhibits.title: Peripheral Blood Smear
exhibits.content: Impression: Presence of schistocytes (fragmented, helmet-shaped red blood cells). Marked polychromasia. Low overall RBC count.

exhibits.title: Nurse's Notes
exhibits.content: Current: Sclera are mildly icteric (jaundiced). Urine is dark and 'coca-cola' colored. Client reports right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain.
